Title: Zimbabwean millennial Kirsty Coventry gets Olympic top job
Description: Zimbabwean Olympic swimmer Kirsty Coventry has been elected to head the International Olympic Committee. The two-time gold medalist is marking a whole new set of 'firsts.' (Image credit: Thanassis Stavrakis)

Title: Hollywood filmmaker charged with defrauding Netflix of $11 million
Description: Director Carl Erik Rinsch sold Netflix a sci-fi series. Instead of finishing it, prosecutors allege he spent some of the streamer's money on his own investments, luxury rentals, five Rolls-Royces, a Ferrari, and more. (Image credit: John Sciulli)

Title: UK court finds men who stole $6 million gold toilet guilty
Description: The artwork, titled, America, was stolen from the palace where Winston Churchill was born. (Image credit: WILLIAM EDWARDS/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Farming is uncertain — a trade war makes it more so
Description: Farmers already worry about things like crop prices, the cost of farm supplies and extreme weather.Now, President Trump's signature tariffs — and the federal government under the Trump administration — pose more big question marks.We hear from Ann Veneman, the Secretary of Agriculture under George W. Bush.And Robert Smith and Wailin Wong from NPR's The Indicator from Planet Money report on what economic uncertainty means for one farmer.For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.Email us at considerthis@npr....

Title: Three escalating conflicts in the Middle East threaten the wider region
Description: Three Middle East conflicts have reignited, threatening the wider region. Israel is bombing Gaza, the U.S. launched strikes against the Houthis in Yemen, and Syria's civil war is boiling again.

Title: U.S. military offensive targets Houthi rebels to stop their Red Sea shipping attacks
Description: For more than a year, Houthi rebels have been attacking ships, choking off transit in one of the world's most critical waterways. The Pentagon says it'll stay till the Houthis stop the attacks.

Title: Trump threatens judge pressing DOJ for answers over El Salvador deportations
Description: The chief judge of the federal district court in Washington, D.C., is facing calls for impeachment after blocking one of President Trump's immigration plans.

Title: 3 people face federal charges for Tesla attacks. Are such acts domestic terrorism?
Description: Attorney General Pamela Bondi says the accused are part of a 'wave of domestic terrorism.' Experts say this is a common stance of the federal government and can be used to seek stiffer penalties. (Image credit: Ethan Miller)

Title: Building a Tech Industry in Syria From Scratch
Description: Recently a few hundred people gathered at a Damascus hotel to discuss how to jump-start Syria's tech industry. That sector was basically non-existent during Syria's long civil war. Our correspondent attended the conference and met a young man who fled Syria during the civil war and now is a graduate student at Stanford. His journey illustrates both the possibilities and challenges that lie ahead for Syria.

Title: Judge calls 'woefully insufficient' the Trump administration response to his order
Description: Judge James Boasberg had earlier asked the Trump administration to provide more details about weekend flights that deported hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador — despite his order to turn the planes around. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: Why a DOJ prosecutor resigned, telling coworkers and bosses 'you serve no man'
Description: Former Assistant U.S. Attorney Sean Murphy resigned from the Department of Justice, telling NPR, 'It just was not a Department of Justice that I any longer wanted to associate with.'' (Image credit: Stefani Reynolds)

Title: Trump suspends $175 million in funding to University of Pennsylvania over trans athletes
Description: The University of Pennsylvania found itself at the center of the trans athlete debate when one of its trans students won a series of events during the 2022 swim season. (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: Ben & Jerry's alleges its CEO was fired over its political activism. Here's the scoop
Description: Ben & Jerry's alleges its parent company, Unilever, ousted its CEO in retaliation for social media posts supporting progressive causes. The last few years have been a rocky road for the companies. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Investigators say a Delta jet descended too quickly before Toronto crash last month
Description: Canadian investigators released a preliminary report into last month's Delta Air Lines regional jet rollover landing crash in Toronto. The plane was descending too quickly before it hit the runway. (Image credit: Katherine KY Cheng)

Title: Dark energy is weakening and the universe could (eventually) collapse, study says
Description: The Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) is studying dark energy and the accelerated expansion of the universe. (Image credit: NASA/ESA/CSA/A. Pagan (STScI)/R. Jansen (ASU))

Title: West Bank Palestinians displaced by Israel's military fear they'll never go home again
Description: Even as the war in Gaza continues, Israel's prime minister says a 'larger and more intense front could be opened' in the West Bank, where more than 40,000 have been displaced in the current operation. (Image credit: Xinhua News Agency/Xinhua News Agency via Getty Ima)

Title: Pentagon restores webpages of Black veterans, Navajo Code Talkers and others after outcry
Description: A Pentagon official not authorized to speak publicly said its review to scrub websites of DEI content was too hasty and also used search terms like 'gay,' leading to the flagging of Enola Gay images. (Image credit: Bettmann/Bettmann Archive)

Title: Israel expands its ground offensive in Gaza as Hamas fires rockets back
Description: The Israeli military expanded its ground offensive in Gaza, and killed at least 80 Palestinians in a new wave of strikes Thursday. Hamas fired its first rockets since Israel broke a recent ceasefire. (Image credit: Bashar Taleb)

Title: Do you feel you can exercise your right to free speech? NPR wants to hear from you
Description: NPR wants to know who is feeling more and less free to exercise their free speech rights in this moment. Have you found yourself letting loose more under President Trump or are you holding back?

Title: Beauty from the ashes.' Texas Panhandle recovering one year after the state's largest wildfire
Description: The Smokehouse Creek fire tore through the Texas Panhandle early last year, burning over a million acres in just weeks. In the small town of Canadian, where the devastation was severe, residents say the heartbreak lingers and a full recovery could take years. (Image credit: Rachel Osier Lindley)

Title: Weaponizing antisemitism makes students 'less safe,' says drafter of definition
Description: Kenneth Stern, who drafted a widely used definition of antisemitism, says the Trump administration is using antisemitism claims to stifle speech and debate on the Middle East on college campuses. (Image credit: Stefan Jeremiah)

Title: With Trump's crackdown on DEI, some women fear a path to good-paying jobs will close
Description: Some fear a setback for women and people of color after President Trump revoked a 1965 executive order that required federal contractors to identify and address barriers to employment. (Image credit: Amber N. Ford for NPR)

Title: Ferrets, water testing and future scientists at risk due to DOGE spending cuts
Description: Interior Department employees say they have been scrambling to keep the lights on and do their jobs as budget cuts driven by the Department of Government efficiency team start to bite. (Image credit: Kika Tuff)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Fed holds rates steady due to uncertainty over impact of tariffs on the economy, federal judge declines to block DOGE takeover of U.S. Institute of Peace, Israel launches new ground offensive in Gaza.

Title: Israel launches new ground invasion into Gaza after breaking ceasefire
Description: Israel has launched a new ground offensive in Gaza after it broke the nearly two-month-long ceasefire with Hamas. On Tuesday, a series of airstrikes killed more than 400 Palestinians in the territory.

Title: Zelenskyy and Trump speak after Trump call with Putin
Description: After a phone call with President Trump Wednesday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has agreed to stop striking Russian oil depots and energy infrastructure as part of a ceasefire deal.

Title: Texas continues to be a major player in Trump's immigration enforcement plans
Description: Texas is quickly becoming the epicenter of the Trump administration's deportation promises. A detention center in Dilley, Texas, shuttered during the Biden administration, is reopening soon.

Title: Minneapolis jury convicts nonprofit head in massive pandemic fraud case
Description: A Minnesota nonprofit founder and a restaurant owner were convicted in what prosecutors call one of the largest COVID fraud cases — a $250 million ripoff of publicly funded child nutrition programs.

Title: Musicians who lost instruments in Hurricane Helene get to pick out new ones
Description: In western North Carolina, people who lost musical instruments due to flooding from Hurricane Helene got a chance to pick out new ones for free thanks to help from musicians across the U.S.

Title: Two perspectives on the role of the courts in the early months of Trump's second term
Description: NPR's A Martinez asks Michael Gerhardt of UNC Law School and Margot Cleveland of the New Civil Liberties Alliance to discuss the role of the courts in the early months of the Trump administration.

Title: What warming U.S.-Russia relations could mean for Iran
Description: What do warming relations between Russia and the U.S. mean for Iran? NPR asks Karim Sadjadpour, senior fellow at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, about the complexities.

Title: Federal judge denies request to block DOGE takeover of U.S. Institute of Peace
Description: A federal judge denied a request to block the DOGE takeover of the U.S. Institute of Peace, despite the judge having serious concerns about the tactics DOGE used gain entry to the building.

Title: Sesame Street
Description: Big Bird, politics, and the ABCs: how a television show made to represent New York City neighborhoods like Harlem and the Bronx became beloved by families around a divided country. This episode originally ran in 2022 as 'Getting to Sesame Street.'To access bonus episodes and listen to Throughline sponsor-free, subscribe to Throughline+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org/throughline.

Title: Malaysia approves a new search for MH370 wreckage in the Indian Ocean
Description: The Boeing 777 plane vanished from radar shortly after taking off on March 8, 2014, carrying 239 people. The plane headed south to the far-southern Indian Ocean, where it is believed to have crashed. (Image credit: Ng Han Guan)

Title: Canada says China executed four Canadians earlier this year
Description: Beijing's embassy in Ottawa said the executions were due to drug crimes and noted that China does not recognize dual citizenship. (Image credit: Adrian Wyld)

Title: Trump to sign order aiming to close the Education Department
Description: The Trump administration has already moved to cut the department's staff by half. (Image credit: Bryan Dozier/Middle East Images)

Title: Israel Launches a New Offensive in Gaza
Description: The two month ceasefire in Gaza has come to an end with Israel conducting airstrikes, killing five Hamas officials along with over 400 others, including many children. The Israeli military has also restarted ground operations in Gaza, sending troops back to areas they had withdrawn from. They say they want Hamas to agree to a new ceasefire deal and release more hostages. But many Israelis are opposed to this return to war. We hear what this resumption of fighting sounds like in Gaza from our producer there. Warning, this episode contains graphic descriptions of war.

Title: Jury says Greenpeace owes hundreds of millions of dollars for Dakota pipeline protest
Description: Experts say the verdict has relevance for free speech issues nationwide. (Image credit: ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Colorado gun control bill could make mass shootings less deadly
Description: Lawmakers in Colorado are close to passing a law restricting guns with detachable magazines. It attempts to mitigate damage during mass shootings and would be one of the strictest gun laws in the U.S.

Title: Immigration agents arrest prominent activist in Denver
Description: ICE agents arrested a high-profile immigrant rights activist in Denver. Jeanette Vizguerra became a symbol during the first Trump administration when she moved into a church to avoid deportation.

Title: Trump is taking a hammer to traditional pillars of soft power
Description: The argument for international aid is in part a moral one, but it's also been about U.S. interests. As then-senator Marco Rubio put it in 2017: 'I promise you it's going to be a lot harder to recruit someone to anti-Americanism, anti-American terrorism if the United States of America was the reason why they're even alive today.'Now, as secretary of state, Rubio serves under a president who is deeply skeptical of the idea of international aid. 'We're giving billions and billions of dollars to countries that hate us,' President Trump said in a speech last month. His administration shuttered the U.S. Agency for International Development. A federal judge said this week that move violated the constitution. What's left of the agency has been folded into the State Department.Trump...

Title: Trump admin. cuts funding for program that tracked Ukrainian children abducted by Russia
Description: NPR's Ailsa Chang speaks with Rep. Greg Landsman, a lawmaker who signed a letter to Secretary of State Marco Rubio asking whether a database of Ukrainian children abducted by Russia had been deleted. (Image credit: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades)

Title: States sense opportunity to hire laid-off federal workers
Description: With the Trump administration trying to lay off tens of thousands of federal workers, some Democratic governors are sensing an opportunity to hire them in state positions.

Title: Israeli airstrikes shattered ceasefire and killed hundreds in Gaza
Description: Hospitals say more than 430 people have been killed in Gaza since Israel shattered a temporary ceasefire in a blitz of airstrikes. Israeli leaders say this is only the beginning of a new offensive.

Title: Judge extends deadline for deportation flight details as DOJ continues to resist
Description: The Justice Department is fighting not to divulge more information about flights that deported alleged gang members to El Salvador. The federal judge is giving lawyers another day to respond. (Image credit: Salvadoran government)

Title: It's your last chance to claim pandemic-era stimulus checks, the IRS says. Here's how
Description: The IRS says some Americans who have not filed their 2021 tax returns could be eligible for a pandemic-era relief payment, as long as they do so by April 15. Here's what to know as Tax Day approaches. (Image credit: Michael Bocchieri)

Title: Louisiana has a long history with French. This immersion school aims to keep it alive
Description: Most Louisianans no longer speak French, but a growing number of schools are now immersing kids in it. At École Pointe-au-Chien, the focus is on teaching local French dialects first. (Image credit: Aubri Juhasz)

Title: Israel has launched a new ground invasion into Gaza after breaking ceasefire
Description: Israel's military launched a new ground offensive in Gaza, sending troops into areas they retreated from during a two-month ceasefire. This comes a day after airstrikes killed more than 400 people. (Image credit: Jack Guez)

Title: Mahmoud Khalil's immigration case moves to New Jersey from New York
Description: The decision offers a venue compromise in the bellwether case, while Khalil's legal team seeks to release him from detention and block his deportation. (Image credit: Selcuk Acar)

Title: Zelenskyy says he plans to discuss Ukraine ceasefire violations in a call with Trump
Description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says he plans to speak with President Trump on Wednesday, following Trump's call on Tuesday with Russian President Vladimir Putin. (Image credit: HEIKKI SAUKKOMAA/Lehtikuva)

Title: Musk, DOGE violated Constitution, judge says. And, when egg prices might drop
Description: A federal judge ruled that Elon Musk and DOGE likely violated the Constitution when shuttering the USAID. And, a look at when egg prices are likely to drop. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: How astronauts adjust when back on Earth after being in space
Description: Astronauts face several risks during spaceflight, including exposure to radiation. (Image credit: Keegan Barber)

Title: Trump's handling of Ukraine and tariffs has NATO rethinking the U.S.-made F-35 fighter
Description: The F-35 was meant as a one-size-fits-all fighter that could be used across NATO. But strained U.S.-Europe relations are giving some member countries second thoughts about the U.S.-built plane. (Image credit: Thomas Lohnes)

Title: Family of U.S. student missing in the Dominican Republic believes she drowned
Description: Sudiksha Konanki remains missing after she disappeared during a spring break trip with friends. (Image credit: Francesco Spotorno)

Title: Movie theater in Miami Beach faces eviction after showing documentary 'No Other Land'
Description: A movie theater in Miami Beach faces eviction after it showed the documentary that won this year's Academy Award. 'No Other Land' follows the displacement of a Palestinian community in the West Bank.

Title: States sense opportunity to hire laid-off federal workers
Description: With the Trump administration trying to lay off tens of thousands of federal workers, some Democratic governors are sensing an opportunity to hire them in state positions.

Title: Two men found guilty in deadliest human smuggling incident in modern U.S. history
Description: Two men have been found guilty in connection with the deadliest human smuggling incident in modern U.S. history. In 2022, 53 people, including 6 children, died inside a tractor trailer in Texas.

Title: Federal judge says USAID shutdown likely violated the Constitution
Description: A federal judge has ruled that Elon Musk and his DOGE team likely violated the Constitution when they effectively shut down USAID. Trump said the administration will appeal the decision.

Title: Israel breaks ceasefire as it strikes Gaza, killing hundreds
Description: A nearly two-month ceasefire between Israel and Hamas ended in a wave of Israeli airstrikes in Gaza that killed hundreds.

Title: Kremlin says it will halt strikes on Ukraine energy sector after talk with Trump
Description: President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a limited ceasefire in Ukraine, where Putin agreed to stop targeting Ukraine's energy facilities for 30 days. Hear about Kyiv's reaction.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Federal judge says USAID shutdown likely violated the Constitution, Ukraine reacts to Trump and Putin phone call on ceasefire deal, Gaza ceasefire ends as Israel launches airstrikes on the territory.

Title: Radio Free Europe CEO expects 'pretty drastic actions' following federal budget slash
Description: Stephen Capus, who leads Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, discusses why his organization is filing a lawsuit against the Trump administration. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: RFERL head discusses the news outlet's future following funding cuts
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel asks Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty President and CEO Steve Capus about the news outlet's future following Trump administration funding cuts.

Title: Former peace negotiator Diana Buttu discusses the ceasefire collapse in Gaza
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel talks with Diana Buttu, a human rights lawyer and former Palestinian peace negotiator, about the collapse of the ceasefire in Gaza.

Title: Cities and counties juggle legal risks and potential rewards of helping ICE
Description: Some local police are eagerly signing up to help ICE, but others are shying away, worried about the legal risks. NPR compares two neighboring counties on New York's Long Island.

Title: Sexual misconduct allegations in UN missions topped 100 in 2024
Description: The United Nations has long been in the spotlight over allegations of child rape and other sexual abuses by its peacekeepers, especially by those based in Congo and the Central African Republic. (Image credit: Salvatore Di Nolfi)

Title: Mexico City bans violent bullfighting, sparking fury and celebration
Description: The decision sparked angry protests from bullfighting supporters and matadors, some of whom tried to breach a police barricade at the local Congress. (Image credit: Ginnette Riquelme)

Title: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty sues Trump administration over canceled contract
Description: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, a government-backed overseas broadcaster, sued the Trump administration in an attempt to get it to release funds appropriated by Congress. (Image credit: MICHAL CIZEK/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Trump and Putin Talk about a Ceasefire in Ukraine
Description: President Trump and President Vladimir Putin of Russia held a lengthy phone call on Tuesday to discuss a possible ceasefire in Ukraine. This is part of Trump's efforts to end the Russia's war in Ukraine and while he didn't get a ceasefire agreement, some progress was made. We hear the latest. And in Ukraine, people are watching these and other developments with concern, skepticism, and with dark humor.

Title: Trump calls for the impeachment of a judge, as lawsuits pile up
Description: To date, 127 legal cases have been filed against the Trump administration's actions since President Trump took office. The cases challenge an enormous range of subjects. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: Here's what happened in the phone call between Trump and Putin
Description: President Trump and Vladimir Putin spoke Tuesday about a potential ceasefire in Ukraine as analysts voiced skepticism about Putin's motivations.

Title: What is the U.S. Institute of Peace and why is Trump trying to shut it down?
Description: Founded during the Cold War to project American soft power and foreign policy expertise, the federally-funded nonprofit think tank is now in the White House's crosshairs (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Israel ends ceasefire with Hamas with airstrikes in Gaza
Description: The Israeli military says the ceasefire with Hamas in Gaza is officially over and a new offensive there has begun. A series of surprise Israeli airstrikes overnight killed more than 400 Palestinians.

Title: Columbia University students react to White House crackdown on protesters
Description: Columbia University students are upset that the school has not taken a more strident stance to protect its students as the Trump administration has used immigration enforcement against protestors.

Title: Measles is spreading. Are you safe?
Description: Measles continues to spread in West Texas and New Mexico. About 300 cases have been reported, since the outbreak began in January - but the actual number is likely higher. The communities where measles continues to spread people are largely unvaccinated. At the same time some isolated measles cases have been reported in a dozen other states - largely linked to international travel.In most of the U.S., vaccination rates are still high enough to stop a major outbreak. But if they continue to fall, we could see long-term consequences of measles in the future. Title: A federal judge says the USAID shutdown likely violated the Constitution
Description: A federal judge has found that the Trump administration likely violated the Constitution when it effectively shuttered the U.S. Agency for International Development. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: 4 things to know about Judge Boasberg as he battles Trump over deportation flights
Description: Judge Boasberg's role overseeing a new case that challenges the deportation of alleged Venezuelan gang members to El Salvador has cast an even brighter light on the longtime judge. (Image credit: Valerie Plesch)

Title: Firing federal employees was swift. Unwinding the terminations is proving complicated
Description: Two federal judges have ordered the Trump administration to reinstate thousands of probationary employees it illegally fired. Agencies report they are doing so but placing most of them on paid leave. (Image credit: Laure Andrillon)

Title: Tensions mount as DOJ gives sworn response to judge's questions about deportations
Description: Trump administration lawyers defended the weekend flights that deported hundreds of alleged Venezuelan gang members despite a federal judge's order to turn the planes around. (Image credit: Salvadoran government handout)

Title: Trump and Putin agree to start talks for a ceasefire in Ukraine
Description: President Trump has said he wants to broker an end to Russia's war in Ukraine. This was his second call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the issue. (Image credit: Brendan Smialowski)

Title: Does the U.S. deserve the Statue of Liberty? Not anymore, one French politician says
Description: A French politician suggested the two countries no longer share the values that inspired the gift more than a century ago. The White House sharply rejected his request, which he described as symbolic. (Image credit: Pamela Smith)

Title: German lawmakers approve huge defense and infrastructure spending
Description: Germany's would-be next chancellor, Friedrich Merz, won lawmakers' approval to loosen strict debt rules for higher defense spending as doubts mount about the strength of the trans-Atlantic alliance. (Image credit: Ebrahim Noroozi)

Title: 4 things to know about the Alien Enemies Act and Trump's efforts to use it
Description: President Trump invoked the Alien Enemies Act of 1798 against Tren de Aragua members, provoking a legal fight. Here's what to know about the controversial law, which was last used during World War II. (Image credit: El Salvador presidential press office)

Title: Last of the classified JFK assassination files to be released Tuesday
Description: About 80,000 documents related to the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy are expected to be released, but presidential historians don't expect any bombshell revelations. (Image credit: Jim Altgens)

Title: Fast-er food: A productivity surge at U.S. restaurants
Description: A new study finds that after decades of stagnation, fast-food and other restaurants finally saw a surge in productivity.

Title: Trump tests executive power. And, hundreds killed in Israeli airstrikes on Gaza
Description: A federal judge is requesting the DOJ give a sworn declaration about deportations over the weekend. And, Israel launched surprise airstrikes in Gaza early Tuesday, killing over 400. (Image credit: Eyad Baba)

Title: Segregated facilities' are no longer explicitly banned in federal contracts
Description: The Trump administration cut a clause from federal contracting rules that had been on the books since the 1960s: Companies are no longer explicitly prohibited from having segregated facilities. (Image credit: William Lovelace/Hulton Archive)

Title: In the Missouri Ozarks, residents struggle to rebuild after tornadoes
Description: Twisters that tore through Union County, Missouri killed 6 people. One couple survived against incomprehensible odds in a trailer obliterated by the storm. (Image credit: Jeff Roberson)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Israel has launched a series of deadly strikes in Gaza, how President Trump is testing executive power while facing court orders, the U.S. Institute of Peace subject to a hostile takeover by DOGE.

Title: How President Trump's foreign policy shifts are viewed outside of the Beltway
Description: President Trump has turned much of American foreign policy on its head. Many in Washington, D.C., are critical, but how are Trump's moves playing beyond the Beltway?

Title: Missouri couple faces gut-wrenching loss after storms tear through region
Description: Tornado death tolls don't tell the whole story. One couple survived against incomprehensible odds in a trailer obliterated by the storm to face a heart-breaking search for their lost dog.

Title: Brown University warns students about travel abroad after doctor deported
Description: A Lebanese doctor who was working for a health nonprofit affiliated with Brown University was deported after traveling abroad. Now, the school is warning students and staff about international travel.

Title: Rwanda faces growing pressure for role in Democratic Republic of Congo conflict
Description: Rwanda is widely believed to be backing the rebel group that's taken over much of the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo in the past two months. The DRC has asked groups to sever ties with Rwanda.

Title: Israel launches series of deadly attacks on Gaza
Description: Israel struck Gaza is a wave of deadly attacks, saying they were launched because Hamas was refusing to release more hostages. The move appears to have put an end to the nearly 2-month-old ceasefire.

Title: Trump and Putin to speak about Ukraine ceasefire in phone call on Tuesday
Description: The stakes are high at President Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin are expected to discuss a 30-day Ukraine ceasefire during a phone call on Tuesday.

Title: DOGE staff entered the U.S. Institute of Peace with D.C. police help
Description: The U.S. Institute of Peace, a think tank funded by Congress, was the scene of a hostile takeover by the Department of Government Efficiency. DOGE has tried to install new leadership at the institute. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana)

Title: How President Trump is testing executive power
Description: We take a look at how President Trump has been dealing with and talking about the many court orders aimed at putting the brakes on his plans.

Title: What the courts can do if a president ignores their rulings
Description: What can a court do if a president ignores its rulings? NPR's A Martínez asks Michael Waldman, a constitutional lawyer and the president of the Brennan Center for Justice.

Title: Texas midwife and associate arrested for allegedly performing illegal abortions
Description: A Texas midwife and associate were arrested for allegedly performing illegal abortions. They're reportedly the first arrests under the state's near-total abortion ban enacted in 2022.

Title: The U.S. measles outbreak is growing. Here's what to know
Description: Measles is one of the most contagious infectious diseases known to science – more contagious than Ebola, smallpox or COVID-19. Declining vaccination rates over the past few years, plus a recent outbreak in West Texas, have public health experts concerned. Here's what to know about the science of this virus — plus how to protect against it. For the latest, host Regina G. Barber talks to NPR health correspondent Maria Godoy.Interested in other stories about public health? Tell us what you want to hear about by emailing shortwave@npr.org!Listen to every episode of Short Wave sponsor-free ...

Title: Israel launches deadly series of attack on Gaza
Description: Israel said the early Tuesday attacks were launched after Hamas refused to release more hostages held in Gaza. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Title: He lost his first LA Marathon medal in the fires -- this weekend he got his second
Description: 15-year-old fire survivor Abel Rivera's home in Altadena burned down in January, and he lost everything — including his medal for finishing the 2024 LA Marathon. (Image credit: Elise Hu)

Title: A U.S. airman is charged in death of a South Dakota woman who had vanished in August
Description: Quinterius Chappelle was arrested on a federal charge of second-degree murder in the death of Sahela Sangrait, according to the Pennington County Sheriff's Office. (Image credit: IMAGO/piemags via Reuters)

Title: Harvard will be free for students whose families make $100,000 or less
Description: The expanded financial aid plan will also offer free tuition to families that make $200,000 or less. The move comes after affirmative action was barred from the admissions process. (Image credit: Maddie Meyer)

Title: Is Trump defying the courts?
Description: Oopsie, too late. 'That post on X from the President of El Salvador got retweeted by Secretary of State Marco Rubio over the weekend with a laugh-crying emoji over a headline about a judge's ruling. The judge ordered the Trump Administration not to deport Venezuelans to El Salvador. That came after a Brown University physician in the United States on an H1-B visa from Lebanon was sent back. Even though a federal judge issued an order that she appear at an in-person hearing on Monday.In a court filing today, lawyers for the government said US Customs and Border Patrol officers said they didn't learn of the order until after the doctor was sent back.The administration insists it is not defying court orders. Trump hasn't yet openly and explicitly defied the co...

Title: What we know about the doctor blocked from returning to the U.S. from Lebanon
Description: U.S. officials say a doctor who was legally working in the U.S. was deported to Lebanon because she possessed materials supporting Hezbollah, which the U.S. deems a terrorist group.

Title: Judge seeks sworn declaration from Justice Department in deportation case
Description: At issue was whether planeloads of alleged members of the Tren de Aragua gang were deported despite the judge's order to turn the planes around. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Pentagon website removes, then restores, page honoring Black Medal of Honor recipient
Description: Charles C. Rogers was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Richard Nixon in 1970. But a profile of the Vietnam War veteran was caught in an 'auto removal process,' the Defense Department says. (Image credit: U.S. Army)

Title: Why Are Young Germans Moving to the Extremes?
Description: In Germany's national elections a few weeks ago, one statistic stood out to our Berlin-based correspondent: almost half of young German voters cast their ballot for either the far-right or far-left parties. And the divide between extreme left and extreme right in young people seems to fall along gender lines. We try to find out why it seems the youth in Germany are moving to the extremes.

Title: Navy warship is sent to the southern border to carry out Trump's immigration plans
Description: Capable of holding over 300 crew members and larger than any Coast Guard vessel, the USS Gravely has been assigned to help tighten border security, operating on both domestic and international waters. (Image credit: Michal Fludra)

Title: What Russia and Ukraine want out of talks, as Trump speaks to Putin Tuesday
Description: President Trump will speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, as the U.S. pursues a ceasefire deal in Ukraine. (Image credit: Aurelien Morissard and Pavel Bednyakov)

Title: Trump blames Iran for Houthi attacks on shipping after U.S. strikes in Yemen
Description: Trump blames Iran for Houthi attacks on international shipping (Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

Title: Trump tries to void Biden's pardons, blaming autopen. Many presidents have used it
Description: Trump claims without evidence that Biden's Jan. 6 panel pardons are void because he allegedly used an autopen. Autopens have been popular with presidents for decades. Here's what to know about them. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Forever 21 is bankrupt, again. This time actually could be forever
Description: Once a formidable fast-fashion mall staple, Forever 21 has filed for bankruptcy. The retailer has been a shell of its former self since it first filed for bankruptcy in 2019. (Image credit: Mark Lennihan)

Title: How a firefighter's quick action saved his friend's life
Description: Ronald Osborne was a firefighter for many years. Early in his career, while battling a house fire, his life was in danger. It was another firefighter's quick thinking that saved him.

Title: Red Scare' revisits the fear of Communism that gripped post-WWII America
Description: Writer Clay Risen describes the anti-Communist frenzy that destroyed the careers of thousands of teachers, union activists and civil servants — and connects that era to our current political moment.

Title: A law in New York pushes doctors to be upfront about patients' costs
Description: The law originally banned health care providers from forcing patients to agree to pay medical bills, no matter the cost. Consumer groups say an amended version doesn't go far enough. (Image credit: AmnajKhetsamtip/iStockphoto)

Title: Why are the Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks stuck? An explainer on the latest
Description: Arab mediators are working to reach a new Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal that would secure the release of 12 living hostages out of the 24 still believed to be held alive by Hamas in Gaza. (Image credit: Abdel Kareem Hana)

Title: How Alabama students went from last place to rising stars in math
Description: Alabama is the only state where 4th-grade math scores are higher now than they were in 2019, before the pandemic. This is the story of how the state pulled it off. (Image credit: Charity Rachelle for NPR)

Title: Wholesale egg prices are going down. How soon will it affect your grocery bill?
Description: Economists say the sharp decline in wholesale egg prices is a positive sign, with some anticipating lower prices at grocery stores in a few weeks. (Image credit: Scott Olson)

Title: 2 separate cases place the immigration lens on Boston
Description: Two legal immigrants who flew into Boston Logan International Airport have been denied re-entry into the United States after traveling abroad. One was deported in apparent defiance of a judicial order. (Image credit: Joseph Prezioso)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Storms kill dozens in southern U.S., Trump administration deports more than 200 Venezuelans to El Salvador with rarely used law, two legal migrants denied reentry in Boston after traveling abroad.

Title: U.S. deports hundreds of Venezuelans to El Salvador
Description: The Trump administration has deported more than 200 Venezuelans to El Salvador who it accuses of being gang members with a rarely used law to quickly expel them without due process.

Title: Trump invoking Alien Enemies Act to deport is 'a threat to everyone,' lawyer argues
Description: President Trump justified his use of a wartime law to deport people. The CEO of Democracy Forward argues that the president is using it to claim powers not granted to him under the Constitution. (Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

Title: Lawyer discusses suit against Trump administration over use of Alien Enemies Act
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel asks Skye Perryman, head of Democracy Forward, about the group's lawsuit against the Trump administration over its use of the Alien Enemies Act to justify mass deportations.

Title: Peruvian farmer goes head to head with German energy giant in climate test case
Description: A Peruvian farmer goes head to head with German energy giant, in a climate law test case.

Title: More than 50 universities under investigation as part of Trump's anti-DEI crackdown
Description: More than 50 universities are being investigated for alleged racial discrimination as part of Trump's campaign to end DEI programs that his officials say exclude white and Asian students.

Title: How nuclear deterrence in Europe may change
Description: What does nuclear deterrence look like in Europe now that NATO is unsure whether the U.S. will be a committed partner? NPR speaks with Paul Cormarie, analyst with the Rand Corporation.

Title: Why are Israel-Hamas ceasefire talks stuck? An explainer on the latest
Description: Arab mediators are working to reach a new Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal that would secure the release of the remaining live hostages

Title: Deadly weekend storms kill at least 3 dozen people across the southern U.S.
Description: Residents in large swaths of the southern U.S. on Sunday took stock of the devastation left in the wake of tornadoes, strong winds and dust storms that left at least 37 dead.

Title: I think he knew': Mahmoud Khalil's wife on his detention and her search for answers
Description: On March 8, Mahmoud Khalil, a pro-Palestinian activist and former Columbia University graduate student, was detained by federal agents. His wife, Noor Abdalla, witnessed the arrest. (Image credit: Mostafa Bassim)

Title: I think he knew': Mahmoud Khalil's wife on his detention and her search for answers
Description: When Columbia University protester Mahmoud Khalil was arrested, it happened right in front of his wife, Noor Abdalla, who is eight-months pregnant with their first child. NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Abdalla about her experience.

Title: Two legal migrants denied reentry into the U.S. after traveling abroad
Description: Two legal immigrants who flew into Boston Logan International Airport have been denied re-entry into the United States after traveling abroad. One of the two was deported in apparent defiance of a judicial order.

Title: The Hollywood Forever Cemetary is running out of room. So it's expanding ... upward
Description: The Hollywood Forever Cemetery has been known as the final resting place of many celebrities. Now, it's adding a high-rise mausoleum to deal with shrinking space in high-density Los Angeles.

Title: Voice of America gutted as Trump administration puts journalists on indefinite leave
Description: Voice of America is mostly silent after the Trump administration ordered hundreds of journalists locked out of their offices and put on indefinite leave.

Title: What to know about CECOT, El Salvador's mega-prison for gang members
Description: The mega-prison in El Salvador, where visitation, recreation and education are not allowed, has became the latest tool in President Donald Trump's crackdown on immigration. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Residents survey the aftermath of deadly weekend storms across the southern U.S.
Description: Officials are still assessing the scale of property damage in several states after an outbreak of twisters and dust storms hit the region over the weekend that left dozens dead. (Image credit: Jeff Roberson)

Title: Never give up - one Gaza boy's story trying to survive in Gaza
Description: Nearly 40, 000.That's the United Nations estimate for the number of children who have been killed or injured since Israel began its war with Hamas some 18 months ago. Last year, NPR profiled one injured Gazan boy, Nimer Sadi al-Nimer, who was shot five times by the Israeli military while he and his father were gathering food dropped by parachute outside Gaza City. This week, NPR Gaza producer Anas Baba tracked Nimer down to hear what the past year has been like. NPR correspondent Rob Schmitz speaks with Baba about what he learned after reconnecting with Nimer.For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Ap...

Title: Pope Francis seen praying in first photo since his hospitalization a month ago
Description: In the image published online by the Holy See Press Office, the pontiff was seated in a wheelchair and praying in the private chapel of Rome's Gemelli Hospital. (Image credit: Vatican Press Hall)

Title: Thousands of children have been wounded in Gaza. We catch up with one of them
Description: NPR producer Anas Baba reunites with Nimer sadi al nimer, a 12 year old boy who was shot by Israeli forces in Gaza last year.

Title: Former Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte appears before the ICC
Description: Former Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte made his first appearance at the International Criminal Court on Friday to face charges of crimes against humanity.

Title: In the early days of the pandemic, a green space in Seattle was one woman's refuge
Description: In the early days of the COVID lockdown, Eileen Wurst would seek refuge in a green space in Seattle.

Title: Tren de Aragua — all you need to know about the Venezuelan gang
Description: The Trump admninistration has invoked a 227 year old law, the Alien Enemies Act, to target Tren de Aragua, a gang with its roots in the prisons of Venezuela. Who are they and how wide is their reach? (Image credit: YURI CORTEZ)

Title: Hundreds of alleged gang members deported from U.S. despite court order
Description: It was not immediately clear if the deportations happened before or after a federal judge in D.C. on Saturday issued an emergency order that told the administration to stop using wartime powers to deport anyone, and turn around any planes already in the air. (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Pool)

Title: People in the path of destruction of Oklahoma's wildfires survey the damage
Description: People in Oklahoma assess the damage from Friday's wildfires, which destroyed close to 300 homes and other buildings.

Title: As congregations across the country shrink, churches offer space for homeless shelters
Description: Congregations with underutilized houses of worship are trying to convert them to affordable housing or homeless shelters. There are significant challenges.

Title: 51 dead and more than 100 injured in nightclub fire in North Macedonia
Description: A massive nightclub fire killed 51 people early Sunday in North Macedonia 's eastern town of Kocani, and injured more than 100. The blaze broke out during a concert by a local pop group. (Image credit: Boris Grdanoski)

Title: Forget about rare earth minerals. We need more copper
Description: In recent weeks, you've likely heard a lot about rare-earth substances with hard-to-pronounce names, but experts warn that the shortage of another crucial metal, copper, could be just as concerning. (Image credit: Glenn Arcos)

Title: March Madness begins for NPR's College Podcast Challenge
Description: Our 10 finalists for the best college podcasts in the country include students from some familiar schools, and a few surprises.

Title: After 15 months of displacement, a Palestinian reporter finally returns home
Description: Anas Baba is NPR's eyes and ears on the ground in Gaza. He's also one of the only Palestinian journalists working full time for an American news organization in Gaza. Israel has banned international journalists from independent access to the territory throughout this war. But Baba is from Gaza City, and he chose to stay and report when the war began. Today on The Sunday Story, what it's like to cover the war while also living through it. (Image credit: Anas Baba)

Title: NASA's stuck astronauts welcome their newly arrived replacements to the space station
Description: Just over a day after blasting off, a SpaceX crew capsule arrived at the International Space Station on Sunday, delivering the replacements for NASA's two stuck astronauts. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Germany's youth vote is increasingly polarized. Why?
Trump enacts a 1790s law to target 'alien enemies' for detention and deportation
Description: In a presidential action Saturday, Trump invoked the wartime authority Alien Enemies Act, targeting members of the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua to immediate detention and deportation. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Trump orders strikes on Iran-backed Houthi rebels in Yemen and issues new warning
Description: Trump said the U.S. would use 'overwhelming lethal force' until Iranian-backed Houthi rebels cease their attacks on shipping. The Houthis said nine civilians were killed. (Image credit: Osamah Abdulrahman)

Title: Trump Administration say South Africa's Ambassador to U.S. 'persona non grata'
Description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio says he's kicking out the Ambassador from South Africa -accusing him of hating America and hating Donald Trump. (Image credit: Cliff Owen)

Title: Israeli strikes in Gaza kill 9, including aid workers and journalists, witnesses say
Description: Two back-to-back Israeli airstrikes in northern Gaza killed at least nine people on Saturday, according to Gaza civil defense. Witnesses say several of those killed were aid workers and journalists. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Title: Sounds like censorship to me.' O cinema co-founder slams proposed eviction over film
Description: No Other Land has no U.S. distributor, so the filmmakers have had to make one-on-one deals with cinemas. Art house theaters such as O Cinema have been screening the film independently. (Image credit: O Cinema)

Title: Syria's government announces a new Constitution even as it struggles to unite the country
Description: Just over three months since the fall of the Assad regime, Syria's leaders are struggling to build a new, unified country.

Title: Noor Abdalla, wife of detained Columbia University student Mahmoud Khalil, speaks out
Description: In her first broadcast interview, Noor Abdalla speaks about the arrest and attempted deportation of her husband, Columbia University protestor Mahmoud Khalil.

Title: After the strike, New York state prisons are even more short-staffed than before
Description: The state of New York was short on corrections officers before a strike among their ranks. The governor is now barring 2,000 strikers from returning to work.

Title: Trump wants to restart nuclear negotiations with Iran. How likely is he to succeed?
Description: NPR's Scott Simon asks Ali Vaez of the International Crisis Group how Iran may interpret President Trump's letter delivered to Iranian officials this week.

Title: Federal contractors say they're stuck between nondiscrimination laws and anti-DEI orders
Description: Since President Trump took office, federal contractors have been scrambling to figure out how to continue complying with nondiscrimination laws without running afoul of his anti-DEI executive orders.

Title: A Ukrainian refugee on how her life has changed after leaving Western Ukraine for Iowa
Description: NPR's Scott Simon speaks with Ukrainian refugee Nataliia 'Natalie' Matiisiv about the country she left and the country she now calls home.

Title: HUD choked funding to enforce fair-housing laws. Legal aid groups may not survive
Description: Most housing discrimination claims are handled by local nonprofits around the country. They say the Trump administration has hobbled them, and are challenging the cuts as unlawful. (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: A new team and a new attitude, Lewis Hamilton cruises into the 2025 Formula 1 season
Description: Lewis Hamilton has a new team, a new outlook and a new hope. Led by the sport's most successful driver, Formula 1's closest season in recent history starts on Sunday at the Australian Grand Prix. (Image credit: Piero Cruciatti)

Title: Severe weather sparks tornadoes and wind-fueled fires, with Southern U.S. on alert
Description: The most fatalities were in Missouri. Forecasters warned that tornadoes, hail and violent winds continue to threaten states in the Deep South, from Louisiana to Georgia. (Image credit: Brad Vest)

Title: Threat of tornadoes moves south after storm unleashes winds and fans wildfires
Description: The threat of tornadoes moved east into the Mississippi Valley and Deep South on Saturday, a day after a massive storm system unleashed winds that damaged buildings in several central states. (Image credit: Robert Cohen/AP)

Title: They look like Nazi salutes. Here's why some people think they're a joke
Description: Multiple people have given stiff-arm salutes after Elon Musk did it twice on Inauguration Day. Many claim it was a joke but extremism experts worry the once-taboo salute is getting normalized. (Image credit: Angela Weiss)

Title: As enrollment in online college grows, students wonder: Why does it cost more?
Description: Rather than lowering the price, some universities use online courses to subsidize everything else. (Image credit: Getty Images; photo collage NPR)

Title: U.K.'s Starmer convenes 'coalition of the willing' meeting to discuss Ukraine
Description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer is convening a second meeting of global leaders Saturday to discuss the developments regarding the war in Ukraine. (Image credit: Stefan Rousseau)

Title: Arlington National Cemetery stops highlighting some historical figures on its website
Description: Articles, photos and videos that are seen as promoting DEI will be removed under the new approach. (Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin)

Title: Turmoil rocks Columbia University as Trump administration demands changes — or else
Description: The Trump administration delivered an ultimatum to leaders of Columbia University: Make a series of major changes or lose out on billions in federal aid. (Image credit: Jason DeCrow)

Title: Block on Trump's executive orders restricting DEI programs is lifted
Description: An appeals court on Friday lifted a block on executive orders seeking to end government support for diversity, equity and inclusion programs, allowing the orders to be enforced as a lawsuit challenging them plays out. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Transgender veterans' health services in question as VA rescinds guidance on care
Description: In an internal VA memo seen by NPR, the VA says it's rescinding a directive that contains detailed guidance on the kind of care transgender veterans can receive at VA facilities. (Image credit: Tierney L. Cross)

Title: Tesla, led by Elon Musk, warns of export retaliation due to new Trump tariffs
Description: Tesla has joined the ranks of U.S. companies concerned that Trump's aggressive tariff policies may negatively affect global sales. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Trump reclaims a Justice Department reshaped in his wake
Description: The rare speech at the Justice Department comes as the Trump administration has spent the last several weeks trying to reconfigure the agency, including demoting attorneys who worked on cases related to the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, and firing officials who investigated the president himself. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: The NWSL is adopting a tool to protect players from online abuse, commissioner says
Description: NWSL's Jessica Berman says the league is adopting a tool to monitor and protect players from online abuse. The NWSL was scrutinized for not doing more to protect player Barbra Banda from harassment. (Image credit: Katelyn Mulcahy)

Title: Zelenskyy wants U.S. to hit Russia with 'maximum' sanctions if it refuses a ceasefire
Description: Ukraine's president said he hopes the U.S. applies 'maximum additional sanctions' on Russia if it refuses to accept a 30-day ceasefire, describing the Russian leader's 'bravado' as a stalling tactic. (Image credit: Efrem Lukatsky)

Title: More Norwegian ski jumpers have been suspended due to a major cheating scandal
Description: Team officials are accused of altering athletes' suits to enhance their aerodynamics. The suspension by International Ski and Snowboard Federation (IFS) follows last week's FIS Nordic World Ski Championships. (Image credit: Lars Baron/Getty Images)

Title: What to know about Canada's new Prime Minister Mark Carney
Description: Canada has a new Prime Minister, as Mark Carney is sworn into office. He picks up the reins just as Canada is embroiled in a trade war with the U.S.

Title: Understanding President Trump's tough approach on Ukraine
Description: Ukraine agreed to a U.S. proposal for a 30-day ceasefire, and President Trump says it's now up to Russia. This comes after a weeks-long pressure campaign from the White House.

Title: On the anniversary of Texas' largest wildfire, residents say recovery may take years
Description: It's now been one year since the start of the largest wildfire in Texas' history. Residents of hard-hit Canadian, Texas, say the heartbreak lingers on and recovery will take years.

Title: What Happened to Syria's Lost Children?
Description: In Syria about a decade ago, while the Assad regime was focused on crushing an uprising that challenged its rule, it faced a problem. It had too many children in detention, who had been swept up when their mothers were arrested. An NPR investigation has found that hundreds of children were separated from family and placed in orphanages around Damascus by government intelligence agents. They ordered the orphanages to keep this a secret. Now that the Assad regime has fallen, families are searching the Syrian capital for their missing children. We go to Damascus to learn more.

Title: Over 50 universities are under investigation as part of Trump's anti-DEI crackdown
Description: The schools under scrutiny include dozens of state schools and two Ivy Leagues. A number of private schools are also being targeted, including Georgetown, Rice, Vanderbilt, and New York University. (Image credit: Tierney L. Cross)

Title: NASA and SpaceX make second attempt this week to launch astronauts
Description: The arrival of the new crew will pave the way for the return of two astronauts who have been 'stuck' on the station since June of last year. (Image credit: Terry Renna/AP)

Title: A U.S. influencer outrages Australians by snatching a baby wombat from its mom
Description: Outdoor enthusiast Sam Jones left Australia after posting a video of herself separating a baby wombat from its mom on a dark road. Australians are cheering her departure and worrying about the animal. (Image credit: Julian Stratenschulte)

Title: Duterte is declared fit for ICC appearance as his lawyer alleges he was 'abducted'
Description: The former Philippine president, accused of crimes against humanity over his deadly 'war on drugs,' spoke via video link in his initial appearance at the International Criminal Court in The Hague. (Image credit: PETER DEJONG/POOL)

Title: Hamas says it's willing to release the five American hostages in Gaza
Description: Hamas, the militant group the U.S. has labeled as terrorists, says it's willing to release the one living American hostage and bodies of four others it's held in Gaza since the 2023 attacks in Israel. (Image credit: Jack Guez)

Title: NWSL preview: 5 questions that could shape women's soccer this season
Description: Whether you're new to the National Women's Soccer League, or you've been a fan for its past 12 seasons, here's a preview of what you should watch out for when play kicks off this weekend. (Image credit: Jamie Squire)

Title: Trump takes birthright citizenship to the Supreme Court
Description: The president's contention that birthright citizenship is unconstitutional is considered a fringe view because the Supreme Court ruled to the contrary 127 years ago. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Who's in, who's out and who is Billboard's Woman of the Year? Find out in the quiz
Description: If you've been paying attention to international politics, you'll get at least three — yes, THREE! — questions right this week!

Title: Dr. Mehmet Oz, Trump's pick to lead Medicare and Medicaid, gets his Senate hearing
Description: Dr. Mehmet Oz is set to appear before the Senate Finance committee Friday for his confirmation hearing to be the administrator for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. (Image credit: Leigh Vogel/Concordia Summit)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Senate to vote on GOP spending bill as government shutdown deadline looms, Trump to give speech at DOJ about law and order, judges order federal agencies to reinstate thousands of fired workers.

Title: Judges order federal agencies to reinstate thousands of workers fired recently
Description: In a pair of rulings Thursday, judges ordered federal agencies to reinstate thousands of workers who were recently fired. In both cases, the judges said the mass firings appear illegal.

Title: Iranian officials talk nuclear program with Chinese and Russian counterparts
Description: The meeting came days after Iran rebuffed President Trump's proposal for nuclear talks. Trump sent a letter calling for Iran to either enter into negotiations or face possible military action. (Image credit: Getty Images/AP)

Title: Iranian officals meet Chinese and Russian counterparts in Beijing
Description: Iranian officials met with Chinese and Russian counterparts in Beijing on Friday to coordinate their positions on nuclear and other issues.

Title: SCOTUS-birthright citizenship
Description: The Trump administration filed three emergency applications at the U.S. Supreme Court to allow it to implement President Trump's executive order that seeks to limit birthright citizenship. In its filings Thursday, the administration asked the justices to limit the nationwide injunctions in place to the plaintiffs in the case only. This would allow the executive order to take effect otherwise.

Title: Trump administration cuts to DEI even affecting nationwide effort to plant trees
Description: The Trump administration's efforts to end diversity, equity and inclusion initiatives is hitting unexpected targets, including a major nationwide effort to plant shade trees.

Title: Federal employees union national president discusses Trump administration cuts
Description: NPR asks Everett Kelley, national president of the American Federation of Government Employees, about uncertainty for federal workers amid Trump administration cuts and a looming government shutdown.

Title: Joe Maslanka was known for his kind heart and his barroom brawls
Description: Joe Maslanka moved to Collegeville, Penn., in 1971, bought a local bar, kicked out the biker gang that hung out there and moved in upstairs. His family visited StoryCorps for a remembrance.

Title: North Dakota went big for Trump. Now many farmers say they face an uncertain future
Description: North Dakota soybean farmers are anxious about another looming trade war with China. In 2018, the first Trump administration doled out billions in aid to farmers, but some say they still haven't been made whole.

Title: Big March storm system threatens U.S. with tornadoes, blizzards and wildfire risk
Description: A storm system crossing the U.S. threatens to unleash tornadoes Friday in the Mississippi Valley, blizzards in the northern Plains and dry conditions in Texas and Oklahoma that pose a wildfire risk. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Mexicans searching for missing relatives uncover possible mass killing site
Description: Distraught families from across the country have already started reaching out about clothing items they say they recognize. (Image credit: AP)

Title: The Asian elephant population in Cambodia is more robust than previously thought
Description: Some 400 to 600 Asian elephants are believed to remain living in the wild in Cambodia. Researchers said the study's findings underscore the potential of a 'national stronghold' for the species. (Image credit: The Flora & Fauna conservation/AP)

Title: A 2nd judge orders thousands of fired federal employees temporarily reinstated
Description: A federal judge in Maryland found the Trump administration acted unlawfully in firing thousands of federal employees by not first notifying states. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: (Don't) click here to pay your tolls: How you can stop spam texts
Description: Smishing' scams aim to compromise your data and pilfer money. And if you think the problem is getting worse, you're right. (Image credit: Sean Rayford)

Title: Democratic Rep. Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona dies at 77
Description: Democratic U.S. Rep. Raúl M. Grijalva of Arizona, who championed environmental protection during his 12 terms in Congress, died Thursday of complications from cancer treatments, his office said. (Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)

Title: Putin says he has questions about the ceasefire with Ukraine
Description: A White House envoy is in Moscow Thursday to discuss the 30-day of proposed ceasefire with top Kremlin officials. President Vladimir Putin says Russia is open to the idea, but 'questions' remain.

Title: Doesn't make any sense': Mahmoud Khalil's lawyer on govt. efforts to deport him
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Mahmoud Khalil's attorney, Amy Greer, about her client's recent arrest. Khalil, a green card holder, is currently being detained by ICE officers. (Image credit: Spencer Platt)

Title: Mahmoud Khalil's lawyer talks about govt. efforts to deport her client
Description: NPR's Ari Shapiro speaks with Mahmoud Khalil's attorney, Amy Greer, about his recent arrest by ICE officers. The Trump administration has accused Khalil, a green card holder, of supporting Hamas.

Title: Israel targets what it says was an Islamic Jihad command center in Damascus
Description: An Israeli airstrike targeted a building in an upscale neighborhood, destroying an apartment that neighbors said had been vacant for years. (Image credit: Emily Garthwaite for NPR)

Title: Mass graves dug up at Gaza's al-Shifa hospital as survivors search for closure
Description: Survivors mourn those killed by Israel's military as bodies are exhumed from mass graves at Gaza's al-Shifa hospital in another reminder of war's toll.

Title: Ex-Philippine president Duterte to face trial on crimes against humanity charges
Description: Former president of the Philippines Rodrigo Duterte is in custody at the International Criminal Court. He has been under investigation since 2021 for his administration's deadly drug crackdown.

Title: What Cuts to U.S. Aid Mean in Africa
Description: President Trump has derided aid the U.S. provides overseas as rife with fraud. His administration has moved aggressively to eliminate such funding including cancelling contracts already in progress. This is all being challenged in court but the effects are being felt acutely by those providing the aid on the ground in foreign countries. We hear from three providers in Africa.

Title: As global tariff tensions rise, here's the latest on U.S. trade with top partners
Description: President Trump has upended global markets by imposing tariffs on imports from several of America's top trading partners. Here's what to know. (Image credit: Cole Burston)

Title: A man says his stepmom locked him in a room for decades. He escaped by setting a fire
Description: Police in Waterbury, Conn., allege the man's stepmother locked him in his room with limited food and water for over 20 years, until he started a fire using hand sanitizer, printer paper and a lighter. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Trump plans to visit the Justice Department Friday, a rare move for a president
Description: The president is planning to give remarks on 'restoring law and order,' according to the White House. Trump has vowed to end 'weaponization' of the DOJ after having been investigated himself. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Thousands of fired federal workers must be offered reinstatement, a judge rules
Description: Thousands of probationary federal employees fired by the Trump administration must be offered job reinstatement within the next week, a district judge in San Francisco has ruled, because they were terminated unlawfully. (Image credit: Alex Wroblewski)

Title: Trump's hiring freeze has halted local head counts and could threaten the U.S. census
Description: Some towns paid the U.S. Census Bureau to produce new local population counts to try to get more funding. But Trump's hiring freeze derailed their special census plans — and could hurt the 2030 count. (Image credit: Tasos Katopodis)

Title: A Putin aide rejects Trump's 30-day Ukraine ceasefire proposal
Description: As U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff enters talks in Moscow on a Trump administration proposal for a 30-day ceasefire with Ukraine, an adviser to the Russian president rejected the idea. (Image credit: Maxim Shemetov)

Title: EPA targets dozens of regulations. And, 'stranded' astronauts may return to Earth
Description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday plans to reconsider more than two dozen rules. And, astronauts 'stranded' on the International Space Station may be able to return to Earth. (Image credit: Ting Shen/AFP)

Title: What Greenland's elections mean for the island — and the U.S.
Description: This week's vote resulted in a win for pro-independence forces and a rejection of President Trump's rhetoric about annexing the island. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: World waits for Moscow response to ceasefire offer the U.S. brokered with Ukraine, EPA announces dozens of regulations it plans to target, Iran rebuffs Trump hopes on starting nuclear talks.

Title: DHS official defends Mahmoud Khalil arrest, but offers few details on why it happened
Description: Homeland Security deputy secretary Troy Edgar offered few details on the Trump administration's legal reasoning to deport Palestinian activist Mahmoud Khalil. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: DHS Deputy Secretary Troy Edgar discusses arrest of protest leader, deportations
Description: NPR speaks with Department of Homeland Security Deputy Secretary Troy Edgar about the arrest of a student protest leader and the Trump administration's ramped-up deportations of immigrants.

Title: Iran's leader rebuffs U.S. over starting nuclear program talks
Description: Iran's supreme leader rebuffed President Trump's hopes to start talks over Iran's nuclear program.

Title: President Trump's attempts to shrink government target civil rights efforts
Description: At the Labor Department, there's a draft proposal to nearly dismantle an office that investigates discrimination by federal contractors. Some fear that women and people of color will lose protections.

Title: U.S. delegation heads to Moscow after Ukraine agrees to 30-day ceasefire
Description: The U.S. resumed Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing after Kyiv agreed to a 30-day ceasefire. Now, a U.S. delegation is heading to Moscow for talks, hoping they accept terms of the proposal.

Title: How layoffs at the Education Department might affect the agency's core functions
Description: How might layoffs at the Department of Education affect its core functions? NPR speaks with education scholar Beth Akers, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.

Title: Aid workers in Africa discuss the consequences of U.S. cuts to foreign aid programs
Description: NPR's Michel Martin talks about the consequences of deep cuts to foreign aid programs with three aid workers in Africa, where about a quarter of USAID funds were allocated.

Title: Rodrigo Duterte to face trial in The Hague for charges of crimes against humanity
Description: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is in custody at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, where he will face charges of crimes against humanity.

Title: What we know about the search for a U.S. student missing in the Dominican Republic
Description: Sudiksha Konanki is a Virginia resident and a student at the University of Pittsburgh. She was vacationing in Punta Cana with five others when she went missing last week. (Image credit: Francesco Spotorno)

Title: EPA announces dozens of environmental regulations it plans to target
Description: The Environmental Protection Agency didn't provide details about what it wants to do with the regulations — whether it will try to weaken them or eliminate them entirely. (Image credit: TING SHEN/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: A medieval Bishop's ring from more than 800 years ago goes to auction
Description: The ring, discovered by a metal detectorist in the U.K., is estimated to sell for between $19,000 and $23,000 at auction. (Image credit: Noonans)

Title: Judge blocks Trump from enforcing 'chilling' order against law firm
Description: While Trump's executive order takes aim at Perkins Coie, the judge said it 'casts a chilling harm of blizzard proportion across the entire legal profession.' (Image credit: Alex Wong)

Title: Louisiana is locked in a legal battle over its planned execution of a death row inmate
Description: Louisiana has hit a roadblock in its plan to resume executions after a 15-year pause. At issue is the method -- death by nitrogen gas -- an which has been used only a handful of times in Alabama and puts one religious group in particular on edge.

Title: The U.S. buys electricity from Canada. Now it's a focus of the trade war
Description: As a trade war grew this week, Ontario's leader threatened a surcharge on Canadian electricity sold in some U.S. states. The episode highlighted the U.S. reliance on imported Canadian power. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: The latest on the Trump administration's Ukraine-Russia ceasefire proposal
Description: Ukraine has agreed to a 30-day ceasefire in its war with Russia. But there's still no response from Russia to the proposal, which is being brokered by the Trump administration.

Title: Why religious leaders are divided on transgender rights
Description: When Kansas became the 26th state to ban gender-affirming medical care for teens, the Catholic Church and Southern Baptist Convention cheered the move. But not all faith leaders agree. (Image credit: Rose Conlon)

Title: Greenland votes for opposition party that favors a gradual approach to independence
Description: In a big shake up of Greenland's political landscape, a pro-business opposition party is the surprise winner in the country's election. The party favors a slow approach to gaining independence.

Title: India Sees Opportunity in U.S. Tariffs
Description: With the U.S. undertaking a tariff war with countries like China, India sees and opening. As goods from China sold in the U.S. get more expensive, India hopes to lure away manufacturers. But can they do that while avoiding being hit with U.S. tariffs themselves? We go to an Indian manufacturing hub to see what the strategy looks like.

Title: What parents, teachers and school choice groups think of Education Department cuts
Description: Teacher unions and some parent groups condemned the cuts, while school choice advocates celebrated them. (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)

Title: Federal judge hears challenge to Mahmoud Khalil's detention
Description: The Trump administration has accused Khalil of engaging in anti-Semitic activity and support of Hamas. The administration wants Khalil deported. But he's a legal permanent resident, and his attorneys deny any involvement with the terrorist group. (Image credit: Adrian Florido)

Title: Rodrigo Duterte is in custody in The Hague for crimes against humanity trial
Description: The former Philippine president is the first former leader from Asia to face charges at the International Criminal Court. Human rights groups say his violent crackdowns left up to 30,000 dead. (Image credit: Aaron Favila)

Title: What Trump's cuts to the Department of Education mean for schools and students
Description: The DoE is cutting staff, halting grants and pressuring schools on various administration priorities. Washington Post writer Laura Meckler discusses its destabilizing effect on the education system.

Title: Universities across the U.S. freeze hiring as federal funding hangs in the balance
Description: With uncertainties around federal funding for higher education, some schools are cutting back. Experts say that could hurt not only students and faculty, but ultimately make the U.S. less competitive. (Image credit: Mel Musto)

Title: Congress reignites a bipartisan effort to ban hair discrimination
Description: Previous attempts to pass the legislation banning hair discrimination have stalled in Congress. (Image credit: Jemal Countess)

Title: Mediators seek a new deal to release more than half of the hostages in Gaza
Description: President Trump's Mideast envoy Steve Witkoff is taking part in ceasefire talks in Qatar, the most serious Israel-Hamas talks since Trump took office. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Education Department's major cuts to its staff. And, a proposed Ukraine peace deal
Description: The Department of Education said it will cut around 50% of its workforce. And, the U.S. has announced it will be resuming military aid to Ukraine. (Image credit: Gent Shkullaku)

Title: America's clean-energy industry is growing despite Trump's attacks. At least for now.
Description: Clean energy is crucial to meet rising U.S. electricity demand, according to industry analysts and executives. But the Trump administration's actions could slow development. (Image credit: Rick Bowmer/AP)

Title: Taiwanese chip giant's investments in U.S. stir 'silicon shield' security worries
Description: TSMC's plan to invest $100 billion into U.S. production facilities raises concerns that its leverage in securing protection from China may be weakened. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: The European Union retaliates after the U.S. metals tariffs take hold
Description: The European Union on Wednesday announced retaliatory trade action with a series of duties on U.S. products, responding to the Trump administration rise in tariffs on all steel and aluminum imports. (Image credit: Pascal Bastien)

Title: Opposition party wins the most votes in Greenland election amid Trump takeover talk
Description: The Demokraatit Party won the most votes in Greenland's parliamentary elections, a surprise result in an election in the shadow of President Donald Trump's stated goal of taking control of the island. (Image credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: U.S. resumes Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing as Kyiv approves ceasefire, Education Department to cut nearly half of staff, House GOP spending plan to avert shutdown heads to the Senate.

Title: India hopes to bring in more manufacturers as Trump's tariffs on China take hold
Description: India hopes to benefit as President Trump seeks to shift manufacturing companies away from China. But there's an obstacle: Trump's tariffs.

Title: U.S. resumes Ukraine military aid and intelligence sharing as Kyiv approves ceasefire
Description: U.S. weapons and intelligence will flow again to Ukraine as its negotiators agreed on a 30-day ceasefire with top U.S. officials. The U.S. hopes Russia agrees to the terms of the ceasefire.

Title: Greenland votes in an election overshadowed by Trump's plans for the territory
Description: Greenland voters are choosing representatives in an election overshadowed by President Trump's assertions that he wants to make the Danish territory part of the U.S. Hear the latest results.

Title: Arizona AG urges Trump administration to halt federal firings in case to be heard Wednesday
Description: Democratic attorneys general in 19 states sued the Trump administration over its mass firing of federal workers. NPR's A Martinez talks with one of the plaintiffs, Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes. (Image credit: Rebecca Noble)

Title: Arizona AG Kris Mayes discusses suit against Trump administration over mass firings
Description: Democratic attorneys general in 19 states sued the Trump administration over its mass firing of federal workers. NPR's A Martinez talks with one of the plaintiffs, Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes.

Title: Following arrest of pro-Palestinian activist, White House says more arrests coming
Description: Following the arrest of student activist Mahmoud Khalil, the White House says intelligence will be used to identify individuals engaged in 'anti- American, antisemitic, pro-Hamas' activities.

Title: Why Alabama was the only state where math scores improved over pre-pandemic levels
